thread.title: Walk your way out of hospital stays
thread.title_full: Walk your way out of hospital stays

author: Amanda Hoh
title: Walk your way out of hospital stays

organizations.name: centre for clinical epidemiology and biostatistics

text:
Map: Sydney 2000 
Walking an extra 40 minutes every day can reduce the number of days in hospital for Australians over 55 and lower the risk of cancer, new research shows. 
People who increased their steps from 4,500 to 8,800 steps per day spent an average of one less day in hospital every three years, researchers from the Centre for Clinical Epidemiology and Biostatistics at the University of Newcastle found. 
The study, published in the Medical Journal of Australia , reported that even an extra 1,000 steps per day would reduce hospital bed days by 9 per cent. 
"The more active people, the people who were taking about 8,500 steps a day ... had one third of a day less in hospital," Dr Ben Ewald, one of the authors of the study, told ABC Radio Sydney . 
"Any exercise is better than no exercise, and more exercise is better." 
Dr Ewald and his research team recruited more than 2,100 Newcastle residents aged over 55 and recorded their steps via a pedometer for a week from 2005 to 2007. 
The participants then had their hospital data collected for eight years up until March 2015. 
To ensure hospital stays were not associated with existing conditions or illnesses, the researchers excluded follow-up hospital visits in the first two years of the study. Photo: The study found increased walking also reduced hospital admissions for cancer and diabetes. (ABC News: Penny McLintock) 
They also used statistical adjustments to "take out" the effects of variable lifestyle factors including education level, sex, number of comorbidities (such as angina, heart attack, asthma), number of medications, smoking status and alcohol consumption. 
The results showed that the more active people who walked an extra 4,300 steps per day — about three kilometres — needed one third of a day less in hospital for every year of follow up. 
"Considering that a day in hospital costs about $1,800 or $2,000, that is a very sizeable health care saving if we can get people to be more active," Dr Ewald said. 
The study also found that higher step counts were associated with fewer bed days for cancer and diabetes. 
"There were less hospital admissions for cancer in the more active group," Dr Ewald said. 
"Being more active protects you from all types of diseases including cancer." How to get your steps up 
The average person walks about 6,000 steps per day, according to Dr Ewald. 
To achieve a higher step count, he recommended people try to increase their incidental activity. 
"It doesn't have to be done as one big trip, it can be broken up across the day," he said. 
"Walk the kids to school instead of driving them ... walk to the shops instead of driving. 
"Often people meet up for coffee, well it's really better for you to meet up for a walk and go for a bit of a stroll while you're having a chat." 
While the researchers did not measure how vigorously the participants were walking, Dr Ewald said there were extra benefits in upping the energy output. 
"In terms of fitness, you do get something extra for running rather than walking," he said. 
"High intensity is great if you can do it, but if you don't like that sort of thing just walking still has benefits. 
"People should be aiming for 10,000 [steps] which would be better, but 8,000 is a good start." 
The researchers also recommended in the report that health coaching, restricted parking availability and better urban design could help in increasing the physical activity levels of the community.
